Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Multi-Scale Models and Quantitative Experiments of Red Blood Cells Transmigration through Inter-Endothelial Slits in the Spleen

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET - 1706436/1706571
PIs: Peng, Zhangli/del Alamo, Juan Carlos

During their circulation through the spleen, red blood cells are challenged to squeeze through narrow slits between endothelial cells that are much smaller than the red blood cell itself. The squeezing motion leads to large red cell deformations and significant mechanical forces on the cells that can cause cell rupture. Aged or otherwise altered red blood cells become trapped and are removed from the circulation. The goal of this collaborative project is to understand the mechanics of red blood cell transmigration through narrow slits by a combination of experiments and high-fidelity numerical modeling. Microfluidic-based experiments will be used to measure the forces required for healthy and diseased red blood cells to move through slits with well-defined widths and geometries. A multi-scale computational model will be developed to fully characterize red blood cell transmigration through slits in the spleen. The results will show how transmigration depends on the geometrical and mechanical properties of the red blood cell and its environment from the molecular level to tissue level. This research may also contribute to knowledge about other important physiological processes, including inflammation and the metastatic spread of tumors, in which transmigration of cells through narrow slits plays an important role. Elements of this project will be adapted for hands-on demonstrations for high school students, and to excite youngsters and their parents about the importance and behavior of multi-component vesicles.

Squeezing through narrow gaps requires significant mechanical forces and red blood cell deformations, which can lead to bilayer-cytoskeletal detachment, cell volume change, and cell rupture. Despite the importance of transmigration to red cell maintenance, there are no quantitative data available on the deformation and stress distributions of transmigrating red blood cells. A multiscale model of red blood cell transmigration will be developed that accounts explicitly for the lipid bilayer of the cell and its underlying cytoskeleton. A force microscopy technique will be used to measure the mechanical forces experienced by red blood cells while passing through slits of controlled size, stiffness and adhesiveness. Red blood cell deformation will be visualized as they pass through the slits, and the roles of microstructural components of the cells will be examined by pharmacological manipulations. Results from the experiments will be used to validate the computational model. The model in combination with experiment will be used to investigate how molecular alterations affect the filtration of RBCs in the spleen when the microstructural organization of the cells and the splenic environment are systematically altered. Results from these studies will be useful in understanding cellular deformation in physiological processes and in biomedical devices where cells undergo large deformations.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project is to understand the mechanical filtration of red blood cells (RBCs) in the human spleen by combining computational modeling and microfluidic experiments. RBCs with a diameter of 8 micrometers regularly pass through small slits (<1 micrometer) between endothelial cells in the spleen. This process serves as a fitness test and removes old and damaged RBCs.

We developed an accurate computational model of this process by considering the detailed molecular structures of RBCs and the strong hydrodynamic interactions between the cell membrane and the slit walls. For the first time, we systematically validated this type of model by comparing transit time of RBCs through slits and various deformed cell shapes with microfluidic experiments done by our experimental collaborators. In these microfluidic experiments, RBCs are driven by controlled hydrodynamic pressure to pass through biomimetic slits with similar dimensions as the slits in the human spleen. Remarkably, RBCs can pass through slits with a width of 0.38 micrometers under body temperature but are trapped in the same slits under room temperature. We found that this difference is caused by the unfolding of spectrins, the major cytoskeletal proteins of RBCs, under body temperature using our computational model. This finding can only be achieved thanks to the multiscale nature of our model: the unfolding properties of the spectrin at the protein scale is used to predict the altered membrane properties at the cell scale. The predicted critical pressures to drive the RBCs to pass through the slits also match well with the experimental measurements under various conditions. Furthermore, we found that the activation of mechanosensitive channels in the membrane and deformation-induced membrane rupture during the slit passage are unlikely for healthy RBCs but can occur for diseased RBCs with molecular deficiencies. These findings will significantly advance our understanding in the fields of RBC mechanics and physiology, such as how the molecular microstructure of RBC membranes leads to its remarkable flexibility. The splenic filtration studied in this project is the place where RBCs experience the most severe deformation in the human body, and it is an ideal case for studying deformation-induced molecular phenomena such as spectrin unfolding using a multiscale model. Besides RBCs, the outcomes of this project will promote our understanding of other cells passing through constricted spaces, including extravasation of white blood cells during diapedesis and cancer cells during metastasis, in which they pass through the slits between endothelial cells of the blood vessel walls. The multiscale modeling approach developed in this project can be extended to study these more sophisticated cells during transmigrations.

In addition to the above intellectual merit, this project will have significant broader impacts on addressing health issues in society and developing new technologies. For example, in several hereditary blood disorders, such as hereditary spherocytosis, RBCs are prematurely removed in the splenic filtration, which can lead to severe anemia requiring spleen removal surgery. The results from this project, such as the revealed role of spectrin unfolding, can help understand why these mutated RBCs are more vulnerable to splenic filtration and how to design new treatments. Another example is that the malaria-infected RBCs are supposed to be removed in the spleen, but it fails to recognize some of them, leading to further transmission. The critical pressures to pass through the slits predicted in this project for various cell shapes can help understand how these infectious cells survive the filtration, which can used to develop new anti-malaria drugs. Moreover, biotech companies are manufacturing therapeutic RBCs to treat cancers and autoimmune diseases by culturing RBCs with genetic manipulations, but these engineered RBCs need to survive the splenic filtration first. The multiscale computational model developed in this project can be used to predict how these engineered RBCs perform during the splenic filtration. Finally, this project trained two PhDs in biomedical engineering, one master student, and two undergraduate researchers through the Research Experiences for Undergraduates supplement.

 


Last Modified: 08/12/2021
Modified by: Zhangli Peng

Image
  • Comparison of experimentally and numerically observed red blood cell shapes and transit times. Each panel shows the correlation between the shapes and transit times obtained experimentally (top panel) and numerically (bottom panel), for a parachute-shaped RBC (A), and a tip-shaped RBC (B).
    Zhangli Peng, Alex Moreau, Emmanuelle Helfer, Annie Viallat
    Zhangli Peng
    Comparison of experimentally and numerically observed red blood cell shapes and transit times
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The objective of this project is to understand the mechanical filtration of red blood cells (RBCs) in the human spleen by combining computational modeling and microfluidic experiments.
